Author R Package Functions That Extend The Ready4 Framework

Source: vignettes/V_01.Rmd
V_01.Rmd
library(ready4fun)

ready4fun provides classes, methods and functions to support highly standardised approaches to authoring R packages that extend the ready4 framework for open and modular mental health systems models.

ready4fun builds on existing development workflow tools (e.g. devtools) to ensure that ready4 framework R packages are:

  • citable (with a Zenodo generated DOI and an algorithm generated CITATION file);
  • community-friendly (applying deprecation conventions supported by lifecycle);
  • documented (applying a function self-documenting algorithm that extends sinew, deploying a GitHub pages hosted and pkgdown generated website and authoring PDF manuals stored in a GitHub Release via piggyback);
  • internally consistent implementing automated checks to ensure consistency in naming conventions, etc;
  • licensed (via a usethis generated GPL-3 license);
  • quality assured (using continuous integration via GitHub actions and R-CMD-Check); and
  • versioned (applying usethis version increments).

The main class exported as part of ready4fun is ready4fun_manifest in which the metadata for an R package is declared. The two main functions from ready4fun that are most relevant to end users are make_pkg_desc_ls and make_manifest as using both of these functions together provides the optimal means of creating a valid instance of the ready4fun_manifest class. The ready4fun_manifest class and make_pkg_desc_ls and make_manifest functions are designed to be used as part of the workflow supported by the ready4pack package.

Future documentation

It is important to note that the workflows supported by ready4fun functions are designed to be implemented after an empty R package has been created with undocumented functions, authored using the ready4fun house-style, that are saved in sub-directories of your package’s data-raw directory. Guidance for how to apply the house style has yet to be published, but more detailed documentation on using ready4fun will be created in 2022.

Contents

Developed by Matthew Hamilton, Glen Wiesner, Orygen, VicHealth, Victoria University.
